awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Hydrophilic and Hydrophobic Polymers from Boron-Containing Polyolefins
awd_abstract_narration:
Professor Rebekka Klausen of Johns Hopkins University is supported by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry to develop a chemical strategy that can turn a hydrophobic (water-hating) polymer into a hydrophilic (water-loving) polymer.  This method enables the preparation of structures that contain both hydrophobic and hydrophilic segments in precisely controlled amounts and sequences.  Polymers are versatile commodity chemicals commonly found in plastics. The ability to control and change the solvent compatibility of a given plastic has profound implications for its applications.  Fundamental insights arising from this project include novel synthetic methods yielding well-defined functional polymers and insights into the relationship of chemical structure and water solubility. The materials prepared under this project are useful in applications in which hydrophobic and hydrophilic materials are combined, such as the efficient recovery of crude oil from oil spills in marine environments or as durable and solvent-resistant adhesives. This research program provides valuable training to undergraduate and graduate students in the preparation and design of industrially relevant materials and supports the integration of academic and industrial scientific relationships through an educational initiative that brings professional chemists to a university setting to discuss their current research and career trajectories. Additional aspects of the educational initiative focus on the recruitment and retention of talented students from diverse backgrounds into Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) fields.

The goal of this research is to control the hydrophobicity of organic polymers by replacing one or more carbon-carbon (CC) bonds with the isosteric, isoelectronic, and polar boron-nitrogen (BN) bond. A novel azaborine vinyl monomer is prepared and its homo- and copolymerization is studied. Reflecting the central role of organoborane chemistry in organic synthesis, postpolymerization functionalization converts the pendant C-B bond to a C-OH bond. In the course of this work, fundamental research into the reactive intermediate chemistry of unconventional aromatic structures is pursued, novel functional polyolefins are prepared, and structure-dependent properties are elucidated. The methods to be used include organic synthesis, polymerization chemistry, and tools for the characterization of physical properties. The project integrates research and educational endeavors by supporting: (1) a career and professional development seminar series in Baltimore, (2) promoting training and learning in industrially-relevant polymer science, and (3) broadening the participation of underrepresented groups through a summer undergraduate research stipend.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of the award “CAREER: Hydrophilic and Hydrophobic Polymers from Boron-Containing Polyolefins” include scientific impact, investment in research infrastructure, and the professional development of early career scientific researchers.

Intellectual Merit Outcomes. Over the five-year course of this award (2018–2023), we published seven peer-reviewed publications on the topic of a boron-based transformable monomer. Four of those manuscripts include at least one undergraduate researcher as a co-author. A transformable monomer mimics the reactivity of a traditional feedstock for commodity plastics but can be chemically triggered to transform into a different chemical structure. The impact of the discovery of transformable monomers is to make plastics that were conventionally considered impossible to prepare and that possess desirable properties, such as the ability to chance solubility characteristics. This ability could be useful in coatings, such as anti-fog coatings. In addition to our seven published manuscripts, this award also supported the research of several graduate students at Johns Hopkins University and has resulted in two completed Ph.D. dissertations. Over the course of this award, PI Klausen was promoted from Assistant Professor to Associate Professor and received several awards recognizing the impact of her research activities, such as being named one of 2 winners of the 2022 ACS Macro Letters / Biomacromolecules / Macromolecules Young Investigator Award. Two patent applications were also filed related to research activities under this award.

Broader Impacts Outcomes. While conducting research activities related to this award, the PI (Klausen) identified a need for major research infrastructure (a solid-state NMR spectrometer) within the Baltimore-DC region. Working with colleagues at several regional institutions (both research universities and primarily undergraduate institutions), she successfully secured funding for the acquisition of a solid-state NMR spectrometer via the NSF Major Research Infrastructure (MRI) program.

As part of the educational activities conducted under this award, the PI established the Pathways to Your Career seminar series at Johns Hopkins University, which provided professional development and career training for chemistry students. The seminar series is now supported by a JHU Innovation Award. This helps create a competitive Science Technology Engineering Math (STEM) workforce. Indeed, PhD graduates from the Klausen group have secured positions in both academia and industry within the US. Our efforts have also focused on increasing the participation of women, persons with disabilities and underrepresented minorities in STEM and of the 11 co-authors on publications arising from this award 6 are women and 2 are Black.

In summary, the intellectual merit outcomes of this award include research activities that addressed fundamental questions in macromolecular chemistry, such as the synthesis of polymers impossible to prepare from conventional precursors. The broader impacts outcomes include broadening participation, training a competitive and diverse STEM work force, and investing in research infrastructure. 

 


Last Modified: 03/17/2023
Modified by: Rebekka Klausen
